commit.message: Clarifying environment variable substitution in the ES configuration YAML.

nodes.bodyText:
Few things here:

Be sure to wrap paragraphs to 80 characters or less.
I typically replace like with such as for examples, but feel free to ignore that if wanted.
I think the paragraph is clearer without this sentence:


However, settings that accept data structures such as lists also accepted comma-separated strings.

If you decide to keep it, fix the accepted bit.

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            When specifying values for environment variables, you can only use strings. More complex data structures like lists are not supported. However, settings that accept data structures such as lists also accepted comma-separated strings. For example, you can specify multiple values for the `${HOSTNAME}` variable from the previous example:
          
          
            
            You can use comma-separated strings to specify multiple values for environment
          
          
            
            variables. More complex data structures, such as lists, are not supported.
          
          
            
            
          
          
            
            For example, you can specify multiple values for the `${HOSTNAME}` variable:

nodes.bodyText:
This should be [source,yaml]. [source,console] snippets get tested by our CI, which would fail here. This is also just a bit of YAML, not a Kibana console snippet.
You only need four - characters to denote a snippet. I wouldn't do more than that.

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            [source,console]
          
          
            
            --------------------------------------------------
          
          
            
            export HOSTNAME=“host1”, “host2"
          
          
            
            --------------------------------------------------
          
          
            
            [source,yaml]
          
          
            
            ----
          
          
            
            export HOSTNAME=“host1”, “host2"
          
          
            
            ----

nodes.bodyText:
I don't think this works (in bash at least) because it splits the assignment at the space:
$ export TEST_ARRAY="host1", "host2"
$ echo $TEST_ARRAY
host1,

I also think having two quoted strings is confusing, given that we're trying to construct a single string containing both values separated by a comma. Also we don't permit a space in the string. Suggest this:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            export HOSTNAME=“host1”, “host2"
          
          
            
            export HOSTNAME=“host1,host2"

nodes.bodyText:
I think this is also not quite right: you can't actually use a comma-separated string to specify multiple values for an environment variable, you're specifying a single value which Elasticsearch will split up if it was expecting a list.
"More complex data structures like lists are not supported" isn't really right, we do support lists of strings this way (but nothing else AFAIK).
